awd_titl_txt: TWC TTP: Small: Security, Privacy, and Trust for Systems of Coordinating Medical Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
To lower costs and improve outcomes in current medical practice we need integrated interoperable medical systems to provide machine-assisted care, interaction detection, and improved alarm accuracy, to name just a few uses. This project is developing both the theory and practice to ensure the safety of next-generation medical devices by allowing secure coordination and composition, in facilities as small as a local doctor's office or as large as a multi-campus hospital. Connected devices are part of a "medical coordination platform," which allows execution of "clinical workflows," such as having a blood pressure cuff automatically take a reading once an infusion pump stops delivering medication, or determining in real time whether prescribed medications are contraindicated by a patient's past health history.

Such manufacturer- and integrator-agnostic communication is difficult to bootstrap and perform securely, but security is required, since networked insecure systems are fundamentally unsafe. Furthermore, medicine is more complex than many other domains: security and quality of service properties must hold even environments where many different people have physical access to devices and communication infrastructure. Without fully trusting individual components, we must provide strong resource isolation, patient privacy protection, and real-time trust reasoning in highly-dynamic, adversarial, and life-critical systems.

We aim for speedy transition to practice by providing reusable security, privacy, and logging components for existing open medical application platforms, supporting varying hardware capabilities, laws, regulations, and facility-local policies, as well as software for pre-deployment and run-time trustworthiness reasoning about the system and individual devices.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to create flexible security solutions for dynamically composable safe networks of medical devices, from open-ended questions such as "which security properties are needed to achieve safe interoperability" to engineering questions of how to design, build, and test the software which implements these properties. Safety of composable systems is particularly challenging, and has been a very hard problem historically. Developing new ways to reason about the safety and security of whole systems (as opposed to only their parts, piece by piece), will encourage medical devices to be used together, collaboratively, and will increase the speed of innovation much like integrated modular avionics has made aircraft design and construction more nimble. Our work on safety-driven composable security for systems-of-systems will reduce the burden on medical device manufacturers, while at the same time making new systems more secure by providing drop-in tools to bootstrap authenticated and confidential communication.

Results of the project include tools to assist design-time human-driven verification and validation, automatic creation, integration, and enforcement of security modules into existing products without developer effort, tools for run-time monitoring and enforcement of authentication and authorization, and a policy language for expressing security properties as part of device functional properties. Other significant outcomes include improvements and modifications to the Medical Device Coordination Framework (MDCF) "sandbox" for testing connected medical systems and high-assurance middleware concepts and technologies, a development environment for automatically generating device security "drivers" on behalf of developers who may not be security experts (experienced developers can always write their own should they choose), tools for high-assurance identification of devices in order to enforce authentication and authorization requirements, and tailored user interfaces that to encourage appropriate use of security technologies and ensure they are perceived as helpful rather than something that just "gets in the way" of practicing medicine -- a frequent complaint in the real world.

Effects of this work ripple though all aspects of the medical space, from policy and regulation, to design and development, manufacturing, deployment and testing, reasoning about complex systems, to forensic analysis of unexpected events. The insights gained from this project have been disseminated through software, academic publications, have served as inspiration for parts of international standards for medical device security and safety, and contributed to the public policy debate regarding how regulators may address device security concerns (i.e., pair-wise vs. component-wise evaluation and testing). Eventually, this will improve medical care for all of us by helping construct high-assurance networked medical systems, where devices can communicate, and intelligently form a more complete picture of our health and conditions than any single device currently can. This information can be shared with clinicians to help better inform complex care decisions, or may even allow some medical issues to be dealt with automatically, intelligently and safely, by the devices themselves, freeing clinicians to deal with more important tasks. Improved medical device coordination and decision support logic will reduce the incidence of medical errors, alleviate the stress on clinicians, and will ultimately save lives.
